questions.question_text: Which of the following terms is NOT a key CloudWatch concept?
questions.answer_description:
The terminology and concepts that are central to one's understanding and use of Amazon Cloud-Watch are as follows: metrics, namespaces, dimensions, timestamps, units, statistics, periods, aggre-gation, alarms, and regions.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/DeveloperGuide/cloudwatch_concepts.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
CloudWatch uses namespaces to organize and group related metrics, units to specify the measurement units of metrics, and time stamps to indicate the time when metric data is collected. However, "Indexes" is not a concept directly associated with CloudWatch.

questions.answer_description:
Security Groups in VPC operate at the instance level, providing a way to control the incoming and outgoing instance traffic. In contrast, network ACLs operate at the subnet level, providing a way to control the traffic that flows through the subnets of your VPC.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/VPC_Security.html

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Network ACLs (Access Control Lists) in a VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) operate at the subnet level.

questions.question_text: Network ACLs in a VPC operate at the ______.

questions.answer_description:
Versioning allows easy recovery of previous file version.
MFA delete requires additional MFA authentication to delete files.
Won't impact the users current access.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/Versioning.html http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingMFADelete.html

discussion.content:
A. Enable versioning on your S3 Buckets
B. Configure your S3 Buckets with MFA delete
Correct Answers: A & B

A | B are the answers

To prevent accidental file deletion one must enable bucket versioning in the console (A), and activate MFA dele via CLI (B)

Amazon literally says to prevent deletion of objects, you use:
Versioning
2FA
What are we arguing for? It's A and B.
Answer A and B.
Question could have more information like do the users need full permission to bucket if not what type of access do they require if any.

A & C : good answers

C The policy for Read only without impact for users!
A : The versioning for accidental deletion

comments.content: C is wrong because of the first statement. The user's have full read/write access then the question asks what changes can be made without changing their access. A & B are correct answers

We don't know if the users requires write permission. If we restrict write access it may impact users.

A and B would not impact users and will help protect

discussion.content: A & C : good ans

choices.D: Enable object life cycle policies and configure the data older than 3 months to be archived in Glacier
choices.B: Configure your S3 Buckets with MFA delete
choices.A: Enable versioning on your S3 Buckets
choices.C: Create a Bucket policy and only allow read only permissions to all users at the bucket level

questions.question_text:
You use S3 to store critical data for your company Several users within your group currently have lull permissions to your S3 buckets You need to come up with a solution mat does not impact your users and also protect against the accidental deletion of objects.
Which two options will address this issue? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/vpc-network-acls.html

Selected Answer: D
Newly created NACLs will deny everything
Correct Answer: C
I will go with "C"
I will go to with C

Ans - C:
The default network ACL is configured to allow all traffic to flow in and out of the subnets with which it is associated.

Ans - D 
Check question 439. they are similar question

comments.content:
It's C. To check yourself.
ii- on an existing VPC, create a custom NACL and attach it to a subnet... check the rules where you'll find one rule for in and out..... DenyIn/DenyOut (question 439)
ii - Create a new VPC, a default nacl is created, check the rules... where you'll find 2 rules: "100" AllowIn/AllowOut before(c) and "*" being deny.
Correct. The behavior between "default" and "Custom" NACLs are different

It is C, as this is a Default ACL whereas the on in 439 is a custom
 one.

questions.answer_description:
Your VPC automatically comes with a modifiable default network ACL. By default, it allows all inbound and outbound traffic.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/VPC_ACLs.html
questions.question_text: Your VPC automatically comes with a modifiable default network ACL, which by default _____.

choices.C: allows all inbound and outbound traffic
choices.D: blocks all inbound and outbound traffic

choices.B: It the edge location of your web content.
choices.D: It is the AWS region where you run the EC2 instance of your web content.
choices.A: It is a logical grouping of EC2 instances within a single Availability Zone.
choices.C: It is a group used to span multiple Availability Zones.

questions.answer_description:
A placement group is a logical grouping of instances within a single Availability Zone. Placement groups are recommended for applications that benefit from low network latency, high network throughput, or both.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/placement-groups.html
questions.question_text: What is a placement group in Amazon EC2?

discussion.content: The question is not precise. If it's asking about the Cluster Placement group the answer would be A, but for other Placement Groups, the options are not valid.
Correct Answer: A

comments.content: I agree, Spread Placement Group can span multiple AZs, so I did not understand this question.

discussion.content: The question is not precise. If it's asking about Cluster Placement group the answer is ok, however for Spread Placement Groups it's incorrect as the can span multiple AZs.
